awd_titl_txt: Leveraging Scientific Societies for Open and FAIR Scientific Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientific societies are a critical stakeholder and leader in bringing about cultural change toward open data across the sciences. The American Geophysical Union (AGU) has played a key role in being a change agent in open science specifically by leading the Earth and space science communities in enabling research data to be findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable (FAIR). The AGU proposes to host a workshop and one-on-one follow-up conversations with targeted societies within the Earth and space sciences and in adjacent disciplines. The goal of the proposal is to engage and empower more scientific societies on their way to adoption of open science principles through education, tools, materials, and consultation. The intellectual merit is in evaluation of the effectiveness of the open and FAIR data tool suite for societies and their members and in moving societies forward in open science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project "Leveraging Scientific Societies for Open and FAIR Scientific Data"(Grant ID 1838990) expanded on the work of the Enabling FAIR Project (https://copdess.org/enabling-fair-data-project/), a community driven effort establishing data preservation and sharing as a common practice in Earth, space, and environmental science peer-reviewed publications. 

With our success in the Earth, space, and environmental sciences we wanted to share the toolkit we created, and encourage other societies to understand open and FAIR data as well as determine where they can help their researchers. 

The grant initially had two major goals with a third added:

1) host a workshop (1.5 days) focused on the value of open and FAIR data sharing that included scientific societies within the natural sciences and related disciplines and,

2) conduct follow-up conversations with those societies after the workshop to encourage action within those societies and offer support.  

3) collaborate with societies to host a seminar series on data sharing.

These activities were intended to,

A) bring awareness to scientific societies on how they can help meet the aspirations of open and FAIR data,

B) request that societies actively communicate with their members on the importance of open and FAIR data,

C) share resources that are available to support better understanding that support intentional culture change. 

During the June 2019 workshop we had nearly 40 participants representing 18 societies.  Additional conversations were had with participants that could not make it to the meeting increasing exposure to 25 societies. 

Participating societies provided updates on their progress in encouraging and requiring open and FAIR data sharing.  This sharing brought an awareness of both common challenges and those that are more unique, but important in cross-discipline, transdisciplinary, or collaborative efforts. 

There was positive support to continue working together on the challenges around data and software sharing as a broad community. 

Workshop output: Stall, Shelley. (2019). Open and FAIR Data - Meeting of Societies - Workshop Reports. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.6251316

With limitations on travel due to the COVID19 pandemic we added the third goal to the effort to host a seminar series on data sharing. During 2021, we conducted the Data Sharing Seminar Series for Societies, in collaboration with 10 other societies and federations:

  • AAAS/Science
  • American Astronomical Society (AAS)
  • American Chemical Society (ACS)
  • American Meteorological Society (AMS), Board on Data Stewardship 
  • British Ecological Society (BES)
  • Council of Scientific Society Presidents (CSSP)
  • Ecological Society of America (ESA)
  • Federation of American Societies For Experimental Biology (FASEB)
  • Federation of Associations in Behavioral and Brain Sciences (FABBS)
  • International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC)

Each month we held a seminar on different aspects of sharing data.  The final seminar, our "Pinnacle Seminar", is schedule for April 2022 where each of the collaborators will participate in panels that include:

  • Bringing awareness to scientific societies on how they can help meet the aspirations of open and FAIR digital research products and encourage the culture of sharing.
  • Discussing how societies can provide incentives for sharing data and software through actions such as updates to honor and awards criteria. 
  • Sharing current practices and resources for updating publication policy and author guidelines around availability statements and citations for data and software. 

Nearly 800 people registered for the entire series.  An average of 107 attended each event, and there was an additional average of 213 views (as of 20 February 2022) of the materials for each seminar. 

The titles, speakers, slides, and links to the recordings are preserved in our Zenodo Community: https://zenodo.org/communities/data-sharing-seminar-series-for-societies/.  

The seminar series is promoted on: https://WeShareData.org 

We continue this work in an upcoming workshop in March 2022 hosted by AAU, APLU, and AGU to connect the goals of the APARD project with the societies and their researchers.
